SECTION 1

We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This program will help prevent the occurence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies

The City of Pharr believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release). This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Pharr Fire Department is the first responder.

The emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine, where the substances can be "adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area.

The City of Pharr has taken steps to train the operators and supervisors to be knowledge in the emergency response program.  The training includes classroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, all employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.

Stationary Source & Regulated Substances

The Water Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection.  The maximum inventory and threshold quatity for Chlorine is: Maximum Inventory (lbs) 16,000             Threshold Quantity (lbs) 2,500.

ve release scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68.  A dense gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense gas model is required since chlorine is heavier than air.  The model's input parameters are summarized:   SLAB Input Parameters

The City of Pharr has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  This Program includes: safety information on the covered chemicals, hazards reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The city will address the recommendation of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.

The executive summary was copied from the June 15, 1999 City of Pharr Water Treament Plant RMP submitted by Enercon Services Inc to EPA.  The city continues to strive in following the RMP and RMP was revised on May 20, 2009.

Hazard Review Results WTP May 20, 1999/2004/2009

1.Process Safety Information, Questions-Are MSDS available?, Reason-Need Chemical data, consequences-Injury may occur from mishandling chemical., Recommendation-Continue availability of MSDS to all employees.

2. Operating Procedures (OP), Questions-Are there written SOP that cover regulated chemicals?, Reason-to make sure activity is performed in a safe manner., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur from not following SOPs., Recommendations-Revise SOP need to be reviewed and updated as needed.

3. OP, Questions-Are the procedures reviewed annually for accuracy?, Reason-Keep up with process changes., consequence-Using ou

tdated SOPs may result in injury or equipment damage. Recommendations-All SOPs need to be updated as needed.

4. OP, Questions-Does each procedures include the date and authorization signatures of last review?, Reason-Keeps less knowledgeable people from creating SOPs., Consequence-using unapproved SOPs may result in injury or equipment damage., Recommendations-All SOPs need to include number, authorization date and signature, and last date reviewed.

5. Contractor Safety, Question-Are contractors aware of hazards and safety procedures?, Reason-Protect contractors from hazards, consequences-Contractor may get hurt and cause legal problems., Recommendations-All employees have to make sure that contractors are aware of the hazards and emergency proceudres.

6. Training, Question-Is refresher training provided?, Reason-Keep employees up-to date, Consequence Injury or equipment damage may occur if employee forgets traing., Recommedations-Document all training and place records in RMP.

7.Training, Question-Are all personnel informed of any procedures prior to implementation?, Reason-Employee may attempt to use old procedure., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if old procedure is implemented., Recommendation-Verify all employees understand new procedures and document in RMP.

8. Training, Is all training documented?, Reason-Make sure all employees are properly trained., Consequence-Management cannot assume everyone has been trained without some type of documentation procedures., Recommendation-Document all training in the RMP including informal training and formal training sessions.

9. Incident Investigation (II), Question-Are written reports prepared for each incident at the conclusion of the investigation?, Reason-Written reports will be used to determine there is an incident pattern with an employee or a piece of equipment., Consequence-Details are forgotten using verbal reports., Recommendation-Incident reports should be placed in the RMP.

10. II, Qu

estion-Has a system been established to determine and resolve the appropriate response to the incident report's finding?, Reason-Reduce the possibility of a similar incident from occurring., Consequence-Incidents can become rountine if not resolved in a timely manner., Recommendations-Incident reports should include a section to document that the recommendations have been followed.

11. Emergency Response (ER), Questions-Are there suitable methods of notifying personnel of emergencies?, Reason-All employees and contractors need to be informed on when emergencies occur., Consequence-Injuries may occur if employees are not notified of emergencies., Recommendations-Continue monthly testing of leak detectors and alarms for chlorine leaks. Verify that audio and visual methods of notifying all employees on site are sufficient-hand held radios, monitor sirens, beacon, etc.

12. ER, Questions-Do all employees and contractors know the evacuation routes and gather points?, Resaon-Rast egress from an area nad headcount are important during emergencies., Consequence-All personnel may not be accounted for if they do not know where to check in., Recommendations-Revise the ERPs to include evacuation routes and primary and secondary gathering points for employees and contractors. Designate a sheltering in place location at the facility.

13. ER, Question-Do all employees know the proper PPE for each activity?, Reason-Different activities require different levels of PPE., Consequence-Injuries may occur if employees are not properly protected., Recommendations-Containter changeout-shield,respirator,PVC,rainsuit, and chemical resistant gloves. The change out team should consist of 2 trained and outfitted people. Release repair/invetigation chemical resistant suit, SCBA, chemical resistant gloves, rubber boots. The response team should consist of two trained and outfitted people and a backup team similarly dressed out.

14. Compliance Audits, Questions-Are compliance audits performed o

n a rountinebasis? Reason-Personnel and equipment may change over time.  Consequence-Outdated SOPs may lead to injury or equipment damage. Recommendation-Conduct compliance audits every year and document in RMP.

15. Compliance Audits, Questions-Has a system been established to determine and resolve the appropriate response to the compliance audit's findings?, Reason-make sure SOPs are being followed and to verify SOPs are up-to-date., Consequence-Outdated SOPs may lead to injury or equipment damage., Recommendation- compliance audits should include a recommendation section and a section to document that the recommendation have been followed.

16. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Question-What if the container is dropped from the lifting apparatus?, Reason-Do employees know proper lifting techniques and what to do if container is dropped?, Consequence-A dropped container could break open and cause a major release., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include inspections of lifting equipment, proper lifting techniques, and response procedures if a containter is dropped.

17. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Question-Are the wheels chocked during unloading/laoding process?, Reason-Truck could start rolling and cause the container to drop., consequence-A dropped container could break open and cause a major release., Recommendation-Revise SOP to include chocking truck wheels and send a copy to the SOP to chemical vendor.

18. Storage of 1-ton containers of chlorine., Question-Are the container storage cradles adequate for intended purpose?, Reason-Inadequate cradles could allow containers to roll off storage platform., Consequence-Container could be damaged on impact and cause a release., Recommendations-Revise SOP to include inspections of container cradles and replace damaged cradles.  Install container cradles to prevent containers from moving during the loading/unloading process.

19. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Question-What if the containers are no

t empty when removed from service?, Reason-Gases could still escape during handling., Consequences-Injury may occur if perosnnel think the containers are empty and get careless., Recommendations-Revise SOPs and training to emphasize the need to handle the containers as if they are full at all times.

20. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Question- What if automatic swithover system fails?, Reason-Residual will decrease to zero., consequence-Residual discharge limits will not be met., Recommendations- Evaluate if a rotometer is necessary on each of the supply lines for visual indication of which tank is online.  Evaluate if flow sensors are necessary in the system and have them alarm the operators station.

21. Handling 1-ton containers of chlorine, Questions-What if the incorrect chemicals are delivered?, Reason-Purchase requisition may not have been properly placed or filled., Consequence-Residual discharge limits may not be met., Recommendation-Revise SOPs and training to include chemical identification and shipment refusals.

22. Handling 1-ton container of chlorine, Questions-What if the containers are not in good condition?, Reason-Container integrity may be at question., Consequence-Damaged containers are more likely to have a release., Recommendation-Revise SOPs and training to include chemical shipment inspections before containers are unloaded and shipment refusals.

23. Equipemt (EQ), Questions-What if flexhoses rupture while connected online?, Reason-Flexhoses not replaced during routine maintenance., Consequence-The entine content of the container could escape before the leak is detected., Recommendations- Document that flexhoses are replaced following manufacturers schedule. Document that the chlorine sensor at the container properly functions.

24. EQ, Questions-What if flexhose connections open or leak when pressure is applied?, Reason-Incorrectly installed when container where changed. Threaded fitting worn out., Consequence-The entire contents

of the container could escape before the leak is detected., Recommendations-Document that flexhoses are replaced following manufacturers schedule. Document that chlorine sensors around tanks properly function. Reinforce the need to check for leaks after installing new containers or if there is a suspected leak.

25. EQ, Question-What if something is dropped onto container or equipment?, Reason-Tools could be dropped during maintenance activities around containers., Consequence-The containers and/or equipment could be damaged and cause a leak., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include procedures of checking all equipment if something is dropped on the containers and/orequipment.  Also revise the SOP to state the operator will increase frequency of daily inspections to verify that the equipment does not start leaking.

26. EQ, Questions-What if liquid chlorine is withdrawn through the vapor lines?, Reason-There is failure of the regulator. Consequence-EQ damage and potential for release., Recommendation-Revise traiing procedures to include equipment troubleshooting.

27. EQ, Questions-What if cylinder valve cannot be closed during an emergency?, Reason-corrosion could keep valve from being closed., Consequence-Containter contents could escape before emergency repairs could be completed., Recommendation-If possible remove leaking container to a safer area. If possible, roll container over so that the leaking valve is positioned on the top of the tank.

28. EQ, Questions-Do the operators know how to use the B kits and the limitations of the kits?, Reason-Operators may not have been trained on the use of B kits., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if repair kits are improperly used., Recommedation-Revise training SOPs to include B kits use and limitations

29. EQ, Question-What if liquid is trapped between two valves and the temperature rises?, Reason-Operators improperly shut down the supply system., Consequence-The vaporized liquid will expand and could cau

se the line to rupture and cause a release. Recommendation-Revise SOPs to include proper system shutdown. Evaluate if expansion chambers are necessary between two valves.

30. EQ, Questions-What if there is a fire near the containers?, Reason-Nearby grass could catch fire. Electrical panels could catch on fire., Consequences-Pressure within containers could increase to a point where plugs rupture causing a release., Recommendation-Revise SOPs to include proper use of fire extinguishers. Make sure there are the proper types of fire extinquishers in the area. If possible move containers out of the area.

31. EQ, Question-What if operator leaves valve open and disconnects the flexhose?, Reason-Improper training for operators. Consequence-Significant release could occur before valve could be closed.  Recommendations-Document that all operators are properly trained in all procedures.

32. EQ, Question-What if water enters the system?, Reason-Ejector fails to create a vacuum., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur if water enters the system. Water and chlorine gas creates a very corrisive environment that can damage equipment. Recommedation-Document that rountine maintenance includes ejector system.

33. Chlorination System (CS), Question-What if the pressure builds up on the system?, Reason-Ambient temperature increases. Gas flow inhibited., Consequences- Excess pressure could cause a release., Recommendations-Make sure detection systems are in working order.

34. CS, Questions-What if a valve leaks?, Reason-Inadequate preventive maintenance. Improperly installed valve., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may result due to the release., Recommendation-Document on a regular basis that the sensors are properly operating.  Revise SOPs to include proper valve installation and repair procedures.

35. CS, Question-What if there is inadequate flow in the gas line?, Reason-clogged filter., Consequence-Discharge limits for chlorine may not be met., Recommendation-C

hange filters based on manufacturer recommendations or as needed.  Evaluate if pressure switches are necessary to indicate chlorine flow failure.

36. CS, Question-What if the vacuum regulator valve fails?, Reason-Inadequate preventive maintenance. Equipment failure., Consequence-Gas will flow out of the vent tubes on the vacuum regulator., Recommendation-Perform rountine maintenance based on manufacturer recommendation or as needed.

37. CS, Question-What if there is liquid carryover to vacuum regulating valve?, Reason-If heaters fail., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur., Recommendations-Revise SOPs to include heater inspection.  Document that rountine maintenance is being performed on all equipment following manufacturer schedule and procedures.

38. CS, Question-What if there are leaks in the chlorinator?, Reason-Equipment failure, inadequate preventive maintenance, equipment improperly installed., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur due to release., Recommendations-Document that chlorine sensors around the tanks properly function., Review preventive maintenance procedures and training.

39. CS, Question-What if there is a rupture of the pipe from the chlorinator to inductor?, Reason-Equipment failure., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may occur due to release. Discharge limits may not be met., Recommendation-Evaluate if pressure switches are necessary on lines. Document that chlorine sensor properly functions. Increase frequency of effluent testing.

40. CS, Question-What if water pump is not working?, Reason-Power failure. Equipment failure., consequence-Chlorination process is designed to shut down at the loss of vacuum., Recommendations-Verify backup generators are maintained and operational during power failure.  Operators should inspect chlorination process during water pump failure to verify equipment is shut down and there are no signs of releases.

41. General (G), Question-What if there is a power failure?, Reason-Sever

e weather. Utility problems., Consequence-Storage capacity could be exceeded., Recommendation-Verify backup generators and maintained and operational during power failure.

42. G, Question-What if a release occurs during maintenance?, Operators not following proper SOPs., Consequence-Injury or equipment damage may result due to release., Recommendation-review operating and maintenance procedures. Document training.

43. G, Question-What if a release is not detected?, Reason-Sensors not functioning., Consequences-A major release could occur if the release was not detected in a reasonable time., Recommendations-Document that all chlorine sensors properly function.

44. G, Question-What if ambient temperatureis too high?, Reason-Ambient temperature in the summer can exceed 100 F., Consequence-Pressure within containers may increase and cause a release., Recommendation-Keep containers out of direct sunlight. Increase operator inspection round during the summer months.

45. G, Question-What if the ambient temperature is too low?, Reason-Ambient temperature in winter can drop below 32 F., Consequences-Gases may reliquify and damage equipment., Recommendation Verify that the temperature within chlorine container is maintained above 55 F.

46. G, Question-What if there is severe weather?, Reason-Area is prone to severe weather., Consequences-Injury of equipment damage may result due to severe weather., Recommedations-Revise SOPs to include severe weather procedures and document training.
